STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 15, 2022
Jamie Lemay
Marquette/Alger/Schoolcraft MDHHS
234 W. Baraga Avenue
Marquette, MI 49855-4710
RE: License #: CP520201281
Marquette/Alger/Schoolcraft MDHHS
234 W. Baraga Avenue
Marquette, MI 49855-4710
Dear Ms. Lemay:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
July 15, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP520201281
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jamie Lemay, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Marquette/Alger/Schoolcraft MDHHS
Facility Address: 234 W. Baraga Avenue
Marquette, MI 49855-4710
Facility Telephone #: (906) 228-9691
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1990
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(1) An agency shall have a written foster parent/agency
agreement signed by the foster parent and the agency before
initially certifying a foster home for licensure and it should be
reviewed at least annually.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not contain a foster parent/agency
agreement as required.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation. The
placement specifications shall include all of the following:
(a) Age
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the placement
specifications were consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
File one: Report dated 09/30/21 has recommendation with age range of 0-10 years
and the corresponding 3706 identifies an age range of 2-10 years.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation. The
placement specifications shall include all of the following:
(c) Race
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the placement
specifications were consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
File one: No ethnicity identified in the recommendation section of the report dated
02/09/22.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement by
the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
4

One of one borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain a copy of the initial evaluation
with written endorsement as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/7/2021
R 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
One of one borrowed bed file reviewed contained a copy of the current evaluation
however there was not a written endorsement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/7/2021
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
One of three special investigation files reviewed included the last name of children
who were interviewed.
R 400.12404 Placement
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(h) A photograph of the child at the time of placement.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not contain a photograph of the youth as
required.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days.
5

Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan/Initial
Service Plan completed timely.
File one: ISP not completed timely; report due 9/11/2021 and was submitted on
9/13/2021.
File two: USP not completed timely, report due 6/8/2022 and was submitted on
6/11/2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 4.22 Child Welfare Information System
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system which will be the primary tracking
system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
Two of three special investigation files reviewed did not have the report uploaded to
MISACWIS.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
6

Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no corresponding FTM for 12/23/2021 USP.
File two: No service plan development FTM involving youth for 11/30/21, 2/28/22 or
5/27/22 service plan.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Two of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
File one: Parent signature not obtained w/in 30 days of 12/19/2021 PATP, youth
signature not obtained w/in 30 days of 3/29/2022 PATP.
File two: Mother’s signature not obtained w/in 30 days of 2/28/2022 PATP, caregiver
signature not obtained w/in 30 days of 5/27/2022 PATP.
File three: Foster parent/caregiver signature not obtained w/in 30 days of 3/24/2022
PATP.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
7

 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Two of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
File one: Gap in medical passports from 6/23/21-5/1/22, not completed quarterly.
File two: Gap in medical passports from 3/12/21-4/15/22, not completed quarterly.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/7/2021
8/5/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/3/2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Reference specific age range in licensing reports instead of stating “infant”.
 List specific characteristics stated in 324(4) in licensing reports instead of
stating “relative specific”.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect and
substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 12/6/2021 determined the foster parents were
8

threatening a foster child with a handheld drill and the drill injured the foster child. In
addition, the foster child was thrown to the ground during an argument with foster
parent which resulted in a bruise. The family was found to be in violation of licensing
rules and agency policy. The agency revoked the foster home license.
A special evaluation initiated on 2/28/2022 determined the adoptive parents did not
initially allow an adopted child medical treatment after an overdose. In addition, the
adopted child disclosed the adoptive parents pushed her into a staircase and pinned
her against the floor which resulted in her glasses breaking. The family was found to
be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. The agency had already initiated
revocation of the foster home license due to an earlier special evaluation.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
interim inspection completed on 7/30/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
9/7/2021. During the review the agency had nine violations. Three citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency did not any identify any barriers in meeting requirements.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment did not identify any barriers in meeting requirements during this
review period. The Chief Administrator stated staff utilize the Book of Business as
well as Info View to ensure compliance and track data. Staff also utilize a cover sheet
for all service plans that tracks required visits and documentation. In addition,
supervision developed their own methods to track data and trends. Staff also have
been working collaboratively with the MiTEAM Analyst to ensure compliance and
track data.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff did not identify any
areas the agency could improve. Staff were positive about the support and
supervision they receive from supervisors and administration. Each reported that they
felt they were part of a supportive team.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Field Analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert #1: The foster home was in need of a variance due to being in the
process of a remodel.
Resolution: The agency submitted a variance request to DCWL within 24 hours of
being notified of the safety alert. The variance was approved on May 2, 2022.
Safety Alert #2: There is not an approved home study in MISACWIS since the family
relocated. In viewing the home, the upstairs bedroom does not have a latching door or
floor to ceiling walls. No variance is in place. Reported carbon monoxide detector in
9

the basement looks like the rest of the smoke alarms (no distinction so unknown if it is
or is not).
Resolution: The licensing worker conducted a home visit within 24 hours of being
notified of the safety alert. An addendum was completed on April 25, 2022. A variance
for the bedroom not having a door was explored, however the foster family decided to
close their license effective 6/13/2022.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
___________7/15/2022___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 15, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
